close_symbols: type of connection->urh (the URH struct) and its member 'was_closed'
explanation: For MISRA C rule analysis about adding const to pointer targets we must know exactly which objects are read vs written and which APIs require non-const pointers. - struct MHD_Connection: shows fields accessed (daemon, urh, resuming); required to know whether the function modifies the pointed-at connection or its members. - struct MHD_Daemon: shows fields accessed/modified (worker_pool, options, cleanup_connection_mutex, resuming, itc); required to determine whether the daemon object is mutated and therefore cannot be pointed-to via a const-qualified type. - type of connection->urh (the URH struct) and its member 'was_closed': the function assigns to urh->was_closed, so the URH type and that member must be known to confirm a write occurs (thus not const). - MHD_TEST_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME: used in a read of daemon->options; needed to confirm this is only a read of options (const-safe) rather than implying modification. - MHD_USE_THREADS: controls the compile-time assertion referencing daemon->worker_pool; needed to understand conditional code paths that may access daemon->worker_pool. - MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ and MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ prototypes: the function takes &daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex and passes it to these routines; their parameter const-qualification determines whether daemon (or its mutex member) must be non-const. - MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_ (macro/inline): used to inspect daemon->itc; need to know whether it only reads itc or could expand to code that modifies it. - MHD_itc_activate_ prototype: called with daemon->itc; if this function requires a non-const itc pointer or modifies it, daemon and/or itc cannot be const-qualified. Together these symbols let the next analyzer decide whether the pointers in the function could validly point to const-qualified types (i.e., whether any pointed-to object is modified or passed to APIs requiring non-const).
